description: From Middle English word, from Old English word, from Proto-West Germanic *word, from Proto-Germanic *wurdą, from Proto-Indo-European *wr̥dʰh₁om. Doublet of verb and verve; further related to vrata.

entries.meaning: The smallest discrete unit of spoken language with a particular meaning, composed of one or more phonemes and one or more morphemes
examples: I can't believe you want me back.You've got Jen to thank for that. Her words the other day moved me deeply. Very deeply indeed.Really? What did she say.Like I remember! Point is it's the effect of her words that's important.

entries.meaning: The smallest discrete unit of written language with a particular meaning, composed of one or more letters or symbols and one or more morphemes
A discrete, meaningful unit of language approved by an authority or native speaker (compare non-word).

definitionGroups.group: Something like such a unit of language:

entries.meaning: A sequence of letters, characters, or sounds, considered as a discrete entity, though it does not necessarily belong to a language or have a meaning
(telegraphy) A unit of text equivalent to five characters and one space. [from 19th c.]
(computing) A fixed-size group of bits handled as a unit by a machine and which can be stored in or retrieved from a typical register (so that it has the same size as such a register). [from 20th c.]
(computer science) A finite string that is not a command or operator. [from 20th or 21st c.]
(group theory) A group element, expressed as a product of group elements.
The fact or act of speaking, as opposed to taking action. [from 9th c].
(now rare outside certain phrases) Something that someone said; a comment, utterance; speech. [from 10th c.]
(obsolete outside certain phrases) A watchword or rallying cry, a verbal signal (even when consisting of multiple words).
(obsolete) A proverb or motto.
(uncountable) News; tidings [from 10th c.]
examples: Have you had any word from John yet?
I've tried for weeks to get word, but I still don't know where she is or if she's all right.

entries.meaning: An order; a request or instruction; an expression of will. [from 10th c.]
examples: He sent word that we should strike camp before winter.
Don't fire till I give the word

entries.meaning: A promise; an oath or guarantee. [from 10th c.]
examples: I give you my word that I will be there on time.

entries.meaning: A brief discussion or conversation. [from 15th c.]
examples: Can I have a word with you?

entries.meaning: (meiosis) A minor reprimand.
examples: I had a word with him about it.

entries.meaning: (in the plural) See words.
examples: There had been words between him and the secretary about the outcome of the meeting.

entries.meaning: (theology, sometimes Word) Communication from God; the message of the Christian gospel; the Bible, Scripture. [from 10th c.]
examples: Her parents had lived in Botswana, spreading the word among the tribespeople.

entries.meaning: (theology, sometimes Word) Logos, Christ. [from 8th c.]

verbs.description: word (third-person singular simple present words, present participle wording, simple past and past participle worded)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To say or write (something) using particular words; to phrase (something).
examples: Synonyms: express, phrase, put into words, state
I’m not sure how to word this letter to the council.

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete) To flatter with words, to cajole.
(transitive) To ply or overpower with words.
(transitive, rare) To conjure with a word.
examples: Against him  […]  who could word heaven and earth out of nothing, and can when he pleases word them into nothing again.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, archaic) To speak, to use words; to converse, to discourse.

description: Variant of worth (“to become, turn into, grow, get”), from Middle English worthen, from Old English weorþan (“to turn into, become, grow”), from Proto-West Germanic *werþan, from Proto-Germanic *werþaną (“to turn, turn into, become”). More at worth § Verb.

entries.meaning: Alternative form of worth (“to become”).
